author: simon.w.ho
content: the output nonce is more like a result to compare with target based on the input nonce

author: zrowgz
content: Hello all! My name is Eamon, I work as nurse, but have been rooting around down here in the crypto rabbit hole for a while now and was starting to re-learn my basic networking/web dev skills (from an old associates program years ago) to get into the developer side when the pandemic started. Have tried to continue to but, work... Iâ€™m super excited to have heard about this on Bankless podcast and am thrilled to get a chance for consideration on learning and transitioning out of nursing and into blockchain technology with this program! Thank you for the opportunity! Reading a bunch of the messages about everyoneâ€™s skills and knowledge is exciting: to get to potentially work along side you all and ensure Ethereumâ€™s place in the growing global digital economy and the benefits of decentralization that it brings to humanity would be incredible!

author: peter.davies
content: I think a better name for "ouput nonce" would be "score".

author: pipermerriam
content: Relevant to both recent discussion and CDAP in general: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/replace-the-yellow-paper-with-executable-markdown-specification/6430

author: peter.davies
content: I've started on writing a document that describes how Verkle Tries work.

author: ogenev
content: I think this is a great way for an eth newbie like me to try understand the protocol by implementing it., before diving into cutting edge protocol R&D like stateless or state expiry ðŸ˜‹  Just watched EIPIP meeting 33 where eth1.0 specs are discussed too, still confused about ERC and EIP process thought...

author: peter.davies
content: The document I'm working on is more focused on explaining that specifying though.

author: peter.davies
content: Where on the teaching to specifying spectrum do we want to land? My experience of the eth2.0-specs is that if you don't know how Eth2 is supposed to work at a high level they aren't that helpful, but if you want to find out some specific detail they are really good.

author: ogenev
content: I think probably it makes sense to first have eth1.0 specs in a similar way as eth2.0 and then we can try to build tutorials and onboarding guidelines on top of them.

author: potuz
content: This I think it's a great idea. While I agree with <@243183686562873344> that a bare specs repo is not that useful to someone just starting. An annotated version is very useful. And to have that we need first the base specs repo

author: pietjepuk
content: And here I thought you'd prefer the mathematical notation of the yellow paper

author: poojaranjan
content: Hi everyone,Â  I am Pooja Ranjan from the Ethereum Cat Herders group. It's a decentralized support group for the Ethereum blockchain. At present, this group is helping out with developers meeting notes, JSON RPC spec documentation, data collection via survey, sharing upgrade-related information, creating PEEPanEIP video, EIPIP meetings etc.

author: poojaranjan
content: If you may want to consider contributing to the current developers with any of these tasks or any new ideas, join us at the ECH meeting on June 8thÂ at 1500 UTC (https://github.com/ethereum-cat-herders/PM/issues/190)

author: poojaranjan
content: If you can't make it to the meeting, feel free to reach us on the ECH Discord (https://discord.gg/tzYmDmF). Happy to help!

author: pipermerriam
content: For some of you that are brand new to the ecosystem, ech is a great way to get involved.
